metadata.title: A comparison study of cleanup techniques for oil spill treatment using magnetic nanomaterials

A comparison study of cleanup techniques for oil spill treatment using magnetic nanomaterials D.S. Cardonaa, K.B. Debsa, S.G. Lemosb, G. Vitalec, N.N. Nassarc, E.N.V.M. Carrilhod, D. Semensattoe, G. A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Oil spill Influence of sample drying Bionanocomposite Two-layer method Magnetic nanoparticles Material reuse
A B S T R A C T
Magnetic nanoparticles have been successfully used to recovery oil from oil spilled on water. Two different methods, floating and vortex, were employed to promote the interaction of four oil samples with different API (e.g., 10, 20, 28 and 45) spilled on seawater and deionized water with three magnetic materials, namely: magnetite nanoparticles (N); magnetic nanocomposites of yeast biomass provided by ethanol industry (Y); and magnetic nanocomposites of cork powder (C). The magnetic nanomaterials exposed to oil on water were taking out by a neodymium magnet, and the oil recoveries were determined by gravimetric analysis before and after lyophilization. The lyophilization was determinant to guarantee the accuracy of the experiments, and without this step, the masses of oil recovered would be overestimated due to the drag of water during the oil and magnetic material removal process. Three main factors, API, contact method and magnetic material, and two interactions (i.e., API× contact method, and contact method×magnetic material) presented a statistically significant effect on oil recovery. It was observed that oil recovery increases as API decreases, and it was possible to establish a model to predict the amount of recovered oil according to this effect. Higher oil recoveries were also obtained by magnetic nanocomposites of yeast biomass (Y), regardless of the contact method and type of water, recoveries of 23% and 100% for 45 and 10 API, respectively, employing around 20mg of Y on 300mg of spilled oil. These percentages correspond to 0.29 ± 0.01 kg/kg and 15.98 kg/kg of recovering oil by the magnetic procedure. The increase of mass of magnetic material improved the recovery of oils with higher APIs. The reusability of the spent materials presents potential for its application in oil spill cleaning technologies.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Oil spills are an environmental and public health issue due to their potential contamination of soils and waters (surface and groundwater) and complicated remediation (Wang et al., 2010; Elias et al., 2015; Raj and Joy, 2015). Most of the oil spills occur during extraction, transportation, and transfer of the oil between vessels, which generates tremendous environmental impacts (USEPA, 1999; Kingston, 2002). For example, oil spilled reduces the contact area between water and atmosphere, which affects the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) and the chemical oxygen demand (COD), thus hindering the photosynthesis
by aquatic plants and respiration of aerobic marine organisms (USEPA, 1999; Kingston, 2002). The scale of devastation caused by oil spills, such as in Debs et al. (2019), Mexican Golf (2010), Campos-Brazil (2011), and Arkansas-USA (2013) highlights the necessity for new remediation strategies. Moreover, treating the water co-produced with oil and gas is also an issue due to its contamination with emulsified oil and other contaminants (Cakmakce et al., 2008).
Magnetic nanomaterials have been highlighted as a remediation strategy because they can be employed alone, functionalized or incorporated into different conventional adsorbent materials, having the advantage of being easily removed from the solution after use by the

application of a magnetic field (Cozzoli et al., 2012; Atta et al., 2014). Most studies reported for recovering oil from water using magnetic materials estimate oil recovery by comparing the weight before and after the removal of the spilled oil. It may be appropriate because gravimetric methods are absolute and recognized for high reliability and accuracy (Hulanicki, 1995; Richter, 1997).
Although many studies use gravimetric analysis to evaluate the recovery of oil spilled on water by magnetic nanomaterials, there are no standard protocols on how this kind of experiment is done. For example, the disposal of oil on the water surface and the possible advantages of using vortex mixing during the contact of the magnetic nanomaterial with the oil layer are still unclear.
Many works adopt the ASTM F726-12 method as a standard protocol. However, the method does not consider the mass of water that could be recovered with the oil, whether it is emulsified or dragged between the magnetic particles and the magnet. Thus, as the procedure involves gravimetric analysis, the masses of water and salt present in seawater can lead to overestimations. Few studies reported a simple draining step of the magnetic material with the oil recovered (Wu et al., 2014; Jiang et al., 2015; Cojocaru et al., 2017) and only one mentioned a lyophilization step before determining the recovery of the oils by the magnetic material (Debs et al., 2019). Most reported studies have ignored this practice, which represents a possible neglect of the contribution of the mass of water on the mass of recovered oil (Calcagnile et al., 2012; Grance et al., 2102; Gu and Bernard, 2013; Mao et al., 2014; Elias et al., 2015; Ge et al., 2015; Yu et al., 2015; Pan et al., 2016; Tao et al., 2017). In the same way, the influence of oil API remains unexplored and unclear.
In order to avoid the overestimation of the oil recovery capacity of new materials as well as to allow comparisons between recovery capacities established for different materials, we performed simulations of the recovery of oils spilled on waters in two-layer systems aided by gravimetric studies. We investigated the ways to establish a reliable and accurate methodology for the evaluation of the recovery capacity of selected magnetic materials.
This work compares the oil recovery by different in-house prepared sorbents, namely: magnetite nanomaterial (N), magnetic nanocomposite of yeast biomass, a byproduct from ethanol industry (Y), and magnetic nanocomposite of cork powder (C). We simulated small-scale spills with four oils having different API gravities (e.g. 10, 20, 28 and 45) on deionized water (D) and seawater (S). Two methods were applied to promote the interaction between adsorbent materials and the oils: Two-Layer Floating (F) without agitation and Two-Layer Vortex with agitation (V). Moreover, in commitment to the accuracy of the gravimetric analysis, we evaluated the influence of lyophilization as a drying step to eliminate the mass water effect, which could be associated with oils and materials, as well as to determine the solids dissolved in seawater.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Cork powder was obtained from an industry of cork artifacts in São Paulo (Brazil). Yeast Biomass, a residue from ethanol and fermentation industry, was provided by Biorigin (Zilor Group Company, Lençóis Paulista, Brazil). All ACS reagents employed to synthesize the magnetic
materials like FeCl3·6 H2O, FeCl2·4 H2O, HCl, and NH4OH were purchased from Merck (Germany) and used as received without further purification. Oil recovery studies were performed using four different oil samples with 10, 20, 28 and 45 API gravities, provided by Petrobras (Rio de Janeiro, Brazil). Seawater was collected in July 2016 at José Menino beach, Santos (Brazil). The seawater sample was filtered using a quantitative filter of 80 g/m2 and porosity of 6.5 μm, and preserved frozen. High-purity deionized water (R≥18MΩ cm) was obtained from a Milli-Q water purification system (Millipore, USA). All chemicals were used as received without further purifications. In all experiments, a magnetic shaker (Quimis, Brazil), a lyophilization equipment model Enterprise I (Terroni, Brazil), a digital balance with 0.001 g resolution (Shimadzu, Japan) and a neodymium magnet (50× 50×25mm; 0.7 T) were employed. A rotavapor R-210 with a vacuum controller V-850 and a vacuum pump V-700 (Buchi, Switzerland) and a heating bath B-491 (Buchi, Switzerland) were all used in the oil recovery study, operating at 52mbar and 40 °C with a rotation speed of 180 rpm.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of magnetite nanoparticles and magnetic nanocomposites
sections.text: The magnetite nanoparticles (N) were synthesized by employing solutions of 200mg/L FeCl2·4H2O and 134mg/L FeCl3·6H2O prepared in 2.6mol/L HCl, mixed in the proportion of 4:1. The mixture was stirred for 30min at 25 °C and 100mL of 0.7mol/L NH4OH were slowly dropped into the mixture. The resulting suspension containing magnetic nanoparticles (N) of Fe3O4 was centrifuged, and the magnetic precipitate was separated with the help of a magnet, washed with deionized water and rinsed with absolute ethanol before being stored in a desiccator to dry. The same procedure was carried out for the preparation of the magnetic nanocomposites, except that the suspension was heated up to 80 °C before adding the cork powder or the yeast biomass in the proportion of 8:1 to the weight of magnetic nanoparticles. This suspension was vigorously stirred for 30min at 80 °C, and the produced cork powder (C) or yeast biomass (Y) magnetic nanocomposites were washed with absolute ethanol and reserved in desiccator to dry for later use. The synthesized magnetic nanomaterials were previously characterized and employed for adsorptive removal of dye from textile wastewater as reported by Labuto et al. (2018) and Debs et al. (2019).

sections.heading: 2.3. Evaluation of oil recovery from water by magnetic nanomaterials
sections.text:
The experiments were carried out to compare two different methods regarding the capacity of magnetic nanomaterials to recover oils spilled on water. The oil spills were obtained by performing two-layers, i.e., placing the oil samples on the water surface and resulting in two distinct phases that simulate an oil spill without emulsification. Around 300mg of each oil were weighed and dropped on about 300mL of deionized water (D) or seawater (S) at 25 °C, at the time of weighing.
In the first method used to promote the contact between oil and material called Two-Layers Floating (F), the oil remained floating on the surface of water samples as shown on Fig. 1. Around 20mg of the magnetic nanomaterials (N, C or Y) were spread over the oil spilled and left for 2min without any additional action. Then, the magnetic nanomaterials that interacted with the oil were recovered from the water surface by approximating a magnet covered by a known mass of an aluminum foil. The aggregate formed by magnetic nanomaterials, oil
recovered and aluminum foil was weighed. The mass was recorded to evaluate how much the mass of water (and salt, in case of seawater) dragged during the removal influenced the results of the gravimetric analysis. Subsequently, the aggregate was frozen, lyophilized for 24 h, and weighed again to determine the mass of oil recovered without the water pulled with the magnetic nanomaterials. For seawater, the proportional contribution of the salt present in the known volume of water removed during lyophilization was discounted. Triplicates of 10mL of seawater were also lyophilized, and the residue was weighed to determine its contribution in g/L.
In the second contact method called Two-Layers Vortex (V), after placing the oil on water at 25 °C, a vortex with nearly 1.5 cm was created using a magnetic stirrer, and held for 2min allowing the mixing of the oil with the magnetic nanomaterials as shown on Fig. 2. After stirring, the magnetic nanomaterials and adsorbed oil were removed in the same way as described in the first method. All experiments were conducted in triplicates.

sections.heading: 2.4. Statistical analysis
sections.text: The study of oil recovery by magnetic nanomaterials was performed considering the experiments described in Section 2.3 as elements of a multilevel factorial design comprising four factors: oil API (i.e., 10, 20, 28 and 45), contact method (Two-Layers Floating, F, or Two-Layers Vortex, V), type of water (deionized, D, or seawater, S) and nanomaterials used for oil recovery (N, C or Y). The factors presented different numbers of levels, giving rise to a factorial design with 48 combinations (4×2×2×3), which were carried out in triplicate performing 144 experiments. Two responses were employed for this design: the percentage of oil recovered and the mass of water removed.

sections.heading: 2.5. Influence of magnetic material masses on oil recoveries
sections.text: To evaluate how the mass of magnetic material influences oil recoveries, the Two-Layer Floating (F) method was employed. The procedure was carried out placing masses around 300mg of each oil onto about 300mL of deionized water (D) at 25 °C. After this was carried out, increasing masses of Y were spread over the oil spilled and left for 2min without any additional action. Then, the magnetic nanomaterials that interacted with the oil were recovered from the water surface by approximating a magnet covered by a known mass of aluminum foil; and, then, the aggregate formed by magnetic nanomaterials, oil recovered and aluminum foil was recovered and weighed. The mass was recorded to evaluate how much the mass of water dragged during the removal influenced the results of the gravimetric analysis. Following, the aggregate was frozen, lyophilized for 24 h, and weighed again to determine the mass of oil recovered without the water pulled with the magnetic nanomaterials. the procedure was repeated with a new mass of oil and Y until the recovery of the oil reached 100%. The experiments were conduced individually for each oil (10, 20, 28 and 45 API) and by triplicate.

sections.heading: 2.6. Reuse and restore of the spent material and recovery of oil
sections.text:
After the magnetic materials performance experiments, the evaluation of cycles of use and restore of magnetic nanomaterial for oil recovery was conducted only for the Y material using the API 45 oil, since it showed the best efficiency. Upon completing a 100% removal of the API 45 oil on Y, the magnetic nanomaterial was used for another removal cycle to test its reuse capability. In brief, in the first cycle, about 1 g of Y was dispersed over 300mg of API oil spilled over deionized water. The process of removing the magnetic nanomaterial involved with the oil was carried out in the same way as for the procedures with the TLF method.
After the lyophilization and weighing steps for the determination of the oil recovered, the dried magnetic material with oil from the first cycle was dispersed again on a new mass of spilled oil (around 300mg)
over deionized water and removed using the TLF method. This procedure was repeated for more two consecutive cycles, always assuring that 1 g of magnetic material would be added again on the spilled oil as in the first cycle, after determination of the mass of oil recovered in each of the cycles. This procedure was adapted from Franco et al. (2014a,b) who employed alumina nanoparticles capped with petroleum vacuum residue for oil spill cleanup. Thus, the initially recovered oil could increase the uptake of new portions of oil due molecular affinity towards non-polar compound.
After three consecutive cycles of oil recovery-lyophilization, the magnetic nanomaterial was washed with toluene P.A (Sigma-Aldrich, Germany) employing a separation funnel with 8 aliquots of 50mL of solvent for extraction of all 45 API oil recovered and resulting in magnetic nanomaterial restore. The restored magnetic nanomaterial was again lyophilized and reused in a new procedure to remove 45 API oil from water, following the aforementioned procedure. This was conducted to ensure that the magnetic nanomaterial could reestablish the same recovery capacity of the first cycle conducted before the restore study.
The toluene containing the recovered 45 API oil was transferred to a
rotary evaporator to recoup both the solvent and 45 API oil, according to the conditions mentioned in Material and Methods Section and the mass of recovered oil was determined by gravimetry and compared with the total mass of spilled oil in the three cycles of use.

sections.heading: 3.1. Evaluation of oil recover from water by magnetic nanomaterials
sections.text:
Oils dispersed differently on water surface depending on the API and the type of water, as seen on Fig. 3. It is notorious that increasing API promotes higher oil dispersion and that is less intense on seawater. This dispersive behavior may be related to the chemical composition of each oil; the weaker the intermolecular cohesion forces, the more dispersed will be the oil (Israelachvili, 2011). Thus, at first, it would be expected that the type of water would influence the recovery of oil. However, only by carrying out the experiments and statistical analysis of the results this speculation can be discussed.
Table 1 presents the oil recoveries, after water removal by lyophilization, from water with different salt contents (D and S), employing three different magnetic nanomaterials (Y, C, and N) and two methods of contact (V and F) between the magnetic nanomaterials and the selected oils.
Table 2 presents the ANOVA of the response percentage of oil recovered. The factors oil API, contact method, type of water, and nanomaterials were represented by capital letters. Interaction effects were represented by the combination of the letters representing each factor. Five effects were statistically significant at the 95.0% confidence level (p-values < 0.05): three main effects (oil API, contact method, and nanomaterials) and two interactions effects (oil API vs. contact method, and contact method vs. nanomaterials).
Regarding the main effects, Fig. 4 presents the mean values of percentage of oil recovered for each level of the factors, as well as an interval around the means based on Fisher's least significant difference (LSD). If the LSD intervals of two means overlap vertically, the means do not differ significantly, as the results in Table 2. Fig. 4a shows significant differences between the mean values of percentage of oil recovered obtained at each oil API. As the oil API increases, the percentage of oil recovered decreases. This relationship is represented by the linear equation: % oil recovered=115.148 (± 6.947) ─ 1.944 (± 0.241)×API (adjusted r2=0.9551; p=0.017), being possible to predict the potential mass of oil to be recovered knowing its API. The lower the API, the more oil will be recovered. These observations
reinforce that adsorption is not the unique phenomenon that describes the oil recovery by magnetic nanomaterials (Debs et al., 2019). It is not only associated with the type of material used and the physical or chemical interactions between their functional groups and the molecules of oil.
The higher percentage of oil recovery was observed with the TwoLayers Floating method (Table 2, Fig. 4b). The oil recovery did not differ significantly for the two types of water evaluated (Fig. 4c). For the type of material used, Y provides a higher oil recovery, which is significantly different from the recoveries obtained with N and C (Fig. 4d). These last two nanomaterials did not provide different recoveries.
Considering solely the main effects, the maximum oil recovery would be achieved (considering the API) by using the Y material and
the F method, regardless of the type of water where the spill occurred. However, the statistically significant differences in the interaction effects must be considered to understand the combined influence of the main factors on the studied system (Table 2). Fig. 5a shows the behavior of the response regarding the oil API vs. contact method (AB interaction), which points out that there are no significant differences between the amounts of oil recovered by considering the F and V methods for oils with 10, 20, and 28 API gravities. However, oil recovery is higher by performing the F method for a 45 API oil.
The behavior of response regarding the contact method vs. nanomaterial (BD interaction) indicates that Y and N materials provide similar recoveries despite the contact method, but C material recovered more oil when associated to F method (Fig. 5b). The C material provides lower recovery with the V method probably because the buoyancy of

the cork hinders the interaction of the magnetic material with the oil. The evaluation of the interaction effects confirms that the recovery of oil is higher when using the Y material, regardless of the type of water, in the context of an oil spill cleaning simulated by the F method.
As seen, quantitative oil recoveries were only possible for the API 10 oil. Hence, experiments were performed to assess the minimum mass of
magnetic nanomaterial necessary to provide a quantitative oil recovery. The contact method, type of water and magnetic nanomaterial employed in this experiment were chosen based on the earlier discussions– yeast biomass nanomaterials, Two-Layers Floating method and deionized water at 25 °C, considering that there were no differences between the kinds of water employed. Thus, around 300mg of each oil were weighed and dropped on about 300mL of deionized water (D) and different masses of Y (i.e., 20, 40, 80, 120, 360, 420, 480, 800 or 1000mg) were spread over the oil spilled and left for 2min without any additional action. The removal of magnetic materials and the subsequent weighting procedures were conducted in the same way as described in section 2.3. It is important to note that mass increments were only performed when the recovery was not satisfactory, that is, when it was below 100%. All experiments were conducted by triplicates.

sections.heading: 3.2. Influence of lyophilization and water salinity on the accuracy of gravimetric analysis
sections.text:
Water salinity did not show influence on oil recovery in our tested conditions. Thus, it is worth considering that lyophilization prior to gravimetric determination is crucial to produce accurate oil recovery results regardless of the API, magnetic materials and the mode of contact between the magnetic materials and the oil to be recovered (Fig. 6). Lyophilization may be the best method because it eliminates water at low temperature, preventing the loss of volatile substances and preserving the oil's integrity (Cetin et al., 2003). Here, estimates of oil recovery without prior lyophilization range from 1.4 to 8.6 times greater than those obtained after lyophilization. Therefore, if a given investigation did not eliminate water before gravimetric determination of oil recovered, it will overestimate the capacity of recovering oil from
Fig. 6. Influence of lyophilization step on the accuracy of oil recovery experiments (10, 20, 28 and 45 API) performed at 25 °C employing magnetic nanocomposites of Yeast (Y), cork powder (C) and magnetic nanoparticles (N), Two-Layers Floating (F) or Two-Layers Vortex (V) procedures, and deionized water (D) or seawater (S), n= 3.
water because the total mass recovered incorporated some water mass. Furthermore, it is possible to assert that the lower the API, the higher the relative standard deviations and the quantities of water carried with the oil during the magnetic removal process. This fact is probably related to the forces of cohesion between the molecules that compose the oil, like London forces, which intensify the buoyancy process caused by the attraction of the magnetic materials, and the magnet, favoring the
transport of water and oil together (Israelachvili, 2011). Table 3 presents the analysis of variance of the response mass of water removed. In this case, four effects presented p-values lower than 0.05: two main effects (oil API and contact method) and two interaction effects (oil API vs. nanomaterials and, contact method vs. nanomaterials). These results denote that water removal does not depend on the type of water (D or S).
The mean values of mass of water removed did not significantly differ for the pair of oils with 10 and 20 API, and for the pair with 28 and 45 API (Fig. 7a). The mass of water removed when recovering oils with 10 or 20 API is about twice the mass removed with the oils with 28 and 45 API. The drag of water during the process of magnetic recovery of oil is also likely to be influenced by the cohesive forces between the molecules that make up each type of oil. In other words, for oils with higher density and consequent stronger intermolecular forces, the stronger attraction of the oil towards the magnet caused by its association with the magnetic nanomaterials would promote not only a higher drag of oil, as can be observed from the data presented in Table 1, but also favors the drag of contiguous water. Additionally, the higher water mass removed with the V method in Fig. 7b confirms the statistical significance of the contact method (Table 3). The V method stirs the magnetic materials in the solution as well as the oil suspended in water, thus promoting more interactions with the water. This favor dragging water together in the recovery process promoted with the magnetic interactions of the materials and the magnet. No significant differences were observed between the means of the water mass removed for D or S (Fig. 7c) or the nanomaterials used for oil recovery (Fig. 7d). It implies that the water salinity did not influence the water mass removed with the oil. Moreover, despite the materials present different hydrophobicity and hydrophilicity related to their molecular structures, they did not influence the amount of water dragged during oil recovery.
For the C material, the water mass removed have similar behavior to that observed in Fig. 8a., i.e., the higher removal of water occurs for oils with 10 and 20 API (Fig. 8a). However, for the Y and N materials, the water mass removed did not depend on the API. The amount of water mass removed was significantly higher when using the V method for all the materials (Fig. 8b). For the N and C materials, there were no significant differences in the water mass removed when the same method was employed (V or F). However, when compared to other materials, the Y provides both the highest water removal when the V method is applied and the lowest water removal when the F method is used. The characteristics of molecular structures of the materials may explain these responses. Cork is composed by hydrophobic structures such as suberin (45%) and lignin (27%), which impart hydrophobicity and buoyancy to the synthesized magnetic composite (Chubar et al., 2004; Olivella et al., 2011). On the other hand, the yeast cell wall is composed of polysaccharides, such as glucans (30–60%), mannan (25–50%) and proteins (13–15%) that present hydrophilic structures (Reid and
Bartnicki-Garcia, 1976; Magnelli et al., 2002).

sections.heading: 3.3. Influence of magnetic material masses on oil recoveries
sections.text: Fig. 9 shows that it was necessary to increase the mass of Y to obtain more satisfactory recoveries for oils with increasing API. For the 10 API oil, it was possible to recover around 100% using 20mg of the magnetic material. For the other oils, recoveries close to 100% were obtained with 120mg for 20 API, 800mg for 28 API and 1000mg for 45 API. This behavior reinforces that the efficiency of oil recovery is directly related to oil API, which is related to the chemical composition of the oil and, consequently, its interaction with water. In this sense, less yeast biomass magnetic material is required to recover the more viscous and probably more hydrophobic oils, while the lighter and more water dispersible oils, and therefore with less hydrophobicity, required a larger mass of magnetic material to obtain a quantitative recovery. The 28 API oil recovering corroborate the results of Debs et al. (2019), which recovered around 50% employing 50mg of Y. The maximum capacity of 10, 20, 28 and 45 API oil recovery at 100% conditions were15.98 ± 0.20, 3.60 ± 0.27, 0.37 ± 0.01 and 0.29 ± 0.01 kg/ kg, respectively, for just one cycle of use of the magnetic material.

sections.heading: 3.4. Reuse and restore of the spent material and recovery of oil
sections.text:
Fig. 10 shows the mass and percentage of oil recovery by Y materials, during three cycles of recovery-lyophilization and one new first cycle after magnetic nanomaterial restore performed by extracting the oil with toluene. A decrease in the mass and percentage of oil recovered suggests that the capacity of oil recovery was affected. However, the simplicity of the reuse of the same Y mass in three subsequent cycles evidences the possibility of increasing the uptake of oil, leading to a full oil recovery. In the experiment of material reuse in different cycles, it was possible to accumulate in the same mass of Y the equivalent of 0.5813 ± kg/kg of 45 API oil. The procedure of restoring Y with extraction of oil from the magnetic nanomaterial using toluene led to the recovery of 100% of the mass of oil spilled in the three cycles (equivalent to 1.511 ± 0.002 g). The toluene used for oil extraction was also recovered in the rotary evaporation procedure. In pressurized systems it would certainly be possible to use less toluene for this purpose.
The results of reuse of Y after its restoring with toluene denote that the nanomaterial maintained its magnetic behavior and, apparently, lost part of its capacity to recover oil. However, in the material restore, it was decided to keep the lyophilization as drying process even if it does not remove the toluene used in the oil extraction, which could be associated with the material (toluene melting point −93 °C, lower than the freezing process method). To verify the presence of toluene in the restored Y, this material was subjected to rotaevaporation at the same conditions described to 45 API oil recovery and was verified around only 1% of toluene. Although toluene removal by rotaevaporation showed insignificant values in mass loss, it is not possible to affirm that this solvent is not adsorbed in Y, impacting the mass of weighted magnetic nanomaterial employed in the study of evaluation of reuse. The adsorption of toluene by composite of magnetite and carbon nanotubes was already described by Pourzamani et al. (2018), who presented maximum adsorption capacity of 49.8mg/g. However, even considering this possibility, it was still possible the use of restored magnetic nanomaterial to oil spilled recovery from water with efficiency around 70%, evidencing its reusability.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The recovery of oil spilled from water by magnetically based nanomaterials using a magnetic field occurs by the combination of adsorption (lower influence) and thrust caused by the magnetic attraction associated with the intermolecular interactions between the oil
molecules (higher influence). Eliminating water before the gravimetric analysis is critical for the correct inference of oil recovery capacities when using composite materials loaded with magnetic nanoparticles. On the contrary, an overestimation of recovery capacity may take place if water is present. Results reported in percentage of oil recovery support this assertion. If water is previously eliminated, the best oil recovery will occur when the Y material and F method are used combined, regardless of the type of water.
The water salinity does not influence nor the oil recovery nor the mass water thrust with oil. On the other hand, API controls the oil recovery in a linear relationship: the higher is the API, the lower will be the oil recovered. The performed reusability tests indicated that the developed material can be repeatedly reused making it compatible for oil recovery usage.

metadata.abstractText: Magnetic nanoparticles have been successfully used to recovery oil from oil spilled on water. Two different methods, floating and vortex, were employed to promote the interaction of four oil samples with different API (e.g., 10, 20, 28 and 45) spilled on seawater and deionized water with three magnetic materials, namely: magnetite nanoparticles (N); magnetic nanocomposites of yeast biomass provided by ethanol industry (Y); and magnetic nanocomposites of cork powder (C). The magnetic nanomaterials exposed to oil on water were taking out by a neodymium magnet, and the oil recoveries were determined by gravimetric analysis before and after lyophilization. The lyophilization was determinant to guarantee the accuracy of the experiments, and without this step, the masses of oil recovered would be overestimated due to the drag of water during the oil and magnetic material removal process. Three main factors, API, contact method and magnetic material, and two interactions (i.e., API× contact method, and contact method×magnetic material) presented a statistically significant effect on oil recovery. It was observed that oil recovery increases as API decreases, and it was possible to establish a model to predict the amount of recovered oil according to this effect. Higher oil recoveries were also obtained by magnetic nanocomposites of yeast biomass (Y), regardless of the contact method and type of water, recoveries of 23% and 100% for 45 and 10 API, respectively, employing around 20mg of Y on 300mg of spilled oil. These percentages correspond to 0.29 ± 0.01 kg/kg and 15.98 kg/kg of recovering oil by the magnetic procedure. The increase of mass of magnetic material improved the recovery of oils with higher APIs. The reusability of the spent materials presents potential for its application in oil spill cleaning technologies.
